block.p: E.P.A. AUTHORITY IS UPHELD -- In a rebuke of Bush administration policy, the Supreme Court has ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions. [Page A1.]

THE TRIBUNE COMPANY IS SOLD The Tribune Company, the owner of 23 television stations and newspapers like The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, has agreed to a sale to Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate mogul, for $8.2 billion. [A1.]
BUT WHAT ABOUT LOS ANGELES? -- What happens now to The Los Angeles Times, which has been a huge thorn in the side of Tribune? [C1.]
ANALYZING THE SALE -- Taking Tribune private will ease quarterly earnings pressures, but operational challenges remain. The Media Equation: David Carr. [C1.]
FINANCING THE SALE -- Employee stock ownership plans of the sort being used to buy Tribune have not always worked out as hoped. [C4.]
FOR SALE: CHICAGO CUBS -- As part of the Tribune deal, the Chicago Cubs will be sold. One of the potential buyers could be Mark Cuban, owner of the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks. [D1.]

GOOGLE TO SELL TV ADS -- Google plans to begin selling television ads on all national satellite channels on EchoStar's Dish Network, bringing its online advertising technology to new markets. Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, above, said the company thought it could ''add value to this important medium by delivering more relevant ads to viewers.'' [C3.]

LENDER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY -- The New Century Financial Corporation, a prominent player in the subprime mortgage business, filed for Chapter 11 protection in the federal bankruptcy court in Delaware. [C1.]
FREMONT GENERAL AUDITOR RESIGNS -- The auditor for Fremont General, another seller of subprime mortgages, has resigned. [C9.]

A SWITCH BY EMI -- EMI Group, the British music giant, has decided to sell songs online through Apple's music service without copy protection, a significant shift in how copyrighted music will be sold in the iPod era. [C1.]

A GREAT YEAR FOR AIRLINES? -- An airline trade group says industry profit will be $4 billion this year. But some analysts think the industry could top the record of about $5.4 billion in profit, set in 1999. [C3.]

BIG TRADE DEAL WITH SOUTH KOREA -- If ratified by Congress, a new trade deal reached between the United States and South Korea would end tariffs on more than 90 percent of the product categories traded between the countries. [C1.]

XEROX BUYS A RIVAL -- Xerox will purchase Global Imaging Systems, which sells printers and copiers, for $1.5 billion as it seeks to expand its reach in the small and midsize business markets. The deal is Xerox's third and largest in the last 12 months as it tries to increase growth in equipment revenue. [C11.]

VERDICT IS OVERTURNED -- A jury verdict in favor of a whistle-blower who charged that the Kerr-McGee Corporation cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties for oil and gas pumped from publicly owned coastal waters has been overturned. [C3.]
STARWOOD CHIEF RESIGNS -- Steven J. Heyer has resigned as chief executive of Starwood Hotels and Resorts after he and the board clashed over his management style. [C2.]
AEROFLOT BIDS FOR ALITALIA -- Aeroflot, the Russian national airline, has made an unexpected offer for all or part of Italy's national airline, Alitalia. [C8.]

STEM CELLS PATENTS IMPERILED -- Three basic patents on stems cells have been revoked in a preliminary decision by United States Patent and Trademark Office, an action that could ease limits on research in the field. [C2.]

MANUFACTURING GROWTH DECLINES -- Manufacturing growth slowed more than expected last month and the cost of raw materials rose adding to concern that inflation is not declining as the economy slows. [C11.]
BID FOR CELLPHONE COMPANY -- AT&T and a Mexican affiliate have bid more than $6 billion for control of Italy's largest cellphone company. [C11.]

EUROPEAN ENERGY DEAL COMPLETED -- The German energy giant E.On has withdrawn its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa in favor of a deal where rival bidders would sell E.On part of Endesa's assets. [C3.]

LOSING A PERSONAL DEVICE -- Business travelers tired from being on the road can and do lose their personal electronic devices, which can be a unpleasant experience. Not to mention that once lost, the gadgets are rarely recovered. [C6.]
ONLINE

BIOMET OFFICIAL RESIGNS -- Another Biomet executive resigns after an inquiry into the backdating of stock options. That report and more are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business.
Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.

TENET HEALTHCARE, one of the largest United States health care companies, agreed Monday to pay a $10 million civil penalty to settle charges that it failed to disclose that its earnings growth from 1999 to 2002 was driven by its exploitation of a loophole in the Medicare reimbursement system. (DOW JONES/AP)
